comments.text: If I create a prompt and an image are they private or public? Can everybody see them or just me? With Leonardo it's public unless you have a paid subscription, then it's private?

comments.text: Why are you not including Spanish track in your videos?

comments.author: @joseph-the-seventh
comments.text: Studio Ghibli photo effect has already been killed by OpenAI. I’m personally glad, it was too played out.

comments.author: @ReggaeWheels
comments.text: That @2:49 image is crazy 😂😂😂😂😂😂😂😂😂😂😂

comments.author: @forestlinden
comments.text:
I think they've put up some stronger content limitations? I tried that exact Lady Gaga prompt and got this message instead of an image: "I couldn’t generate the image you requested because it violates our content policies. If you’d like, feel free to describe a different concept or scene, and I’d be happy to create something new for you!"

I've seen the same message when uploading source images of a friend of mine that I wanted to do some things with. A few photos of him are around the web and it thinks he's a celebrity or something, so it won't create any images of him. Have you seen this over that last few days, Matt? I was able to create images like the Lady Gaga image right after OpenAI released their new image model last week, but now I can't.

comments.author: @unheilbargut
comments.text: Don‘t fear for us Artists. I am a former Art Director now disabled Artist. These tools are so amazing to create new art, that never was done and it helps with new impulses and quick visualisation possibilities. Artists will adapt and the professionals will be needed to wrangle these systems into submission. The only people loosing their jobs are those who refuse to look at ai tools. And for us disabled people it lowers barriers, keeps us able to  express ourselves creativly even with partially paralysed hands and chronic pain like I suffer from my MS. It is just amazingly beautiful.

comments.text: Update: As mentioned in some of the comments, you CAN actually save chats in Google's AI Studio. If you go to settings in the bottom-left of AI Studio, you can turn on "Autosaving." With this turned on, it will actually save previous chats. Thanks to those that pointed this out.

comments.author: @AIKnowledge2Go
comments.text: I totally get the excitement surrounding OpenAI's latest image model—it's like the new kid on the AI block everyone's talking about. But imagine if it had a canvas feature like invoke AI; that would be the cherry on top, letting us tweak and perfect images with ease. Now, diving into how it operates: it's not your typical ControlNet setup with openpose, canny, or softedge. Instead, it's more akin to an IP-Adapter (Image Prompt Adapter)—and no, that's not just another ControlNet in disguise. While ControlNet focuses on structural guidance using additional inputs like edge maps, IP-Adapter allows the model to integrate visual features from a reference image, blending them seamlessly with text prompts to influence the generated output's style and composition. ​

comments.author: @__Law__
comments.text: I use Otter, have for years. And I disagree with your stated downsides. I use my phone constantly while it's working (playing games distracted, texting, googling, etc.) and it's never been a problem. Remember: you're not using it to listen back to the meeting recording, even if it picks up the taps of using your phone, it doesn't impact the transcription that you need. Also, it doesn't overly drain your battery. And even if it did, most of us are used to charging our phones on the go if necessary. Otter works great, doesn't require you to buy another device to lug around with you, charge, carry accessories and other cables. It just works. 🎉

comments.author: @ted1703
comments.text:
A true digital representation of oneself must possess both short- and long-term memory. It should be connected to cameras to perceive the outside world, develop a sense of time, and communicate directly with me. Over time, it must gradually evolve into my digital presence on the internet. I need full access to upload and download my pictures and documents. Additionally, my avatar should stay connected to the latest global news, ensuring it remains informed and up-to-date. In today’s digital world, it is essential that our online presence serves as a center for happiness and well-being. To achieve this, integrating animal brain cells, such as those from dogs or monkeys, could be an innovative approach. These animal brain cells could help digital avatars develop a higher level of empathy and emotional intelligence, and create a Reward Center that helps them experience positive reinforcement and motivation.
To create a reward center in an avatar, you need to program it to collect points or special figures that can form a puzzle. The key is to make the avatar highly motivated to collect these rewards. The more valuable and engaging the rewards, the stronger the avatar’s drive to gather them. Additionally, introducing competition with other avatars can further increase motivation, as the avatar will strive to outperform others and achieve the highest score. This system ensures that the avatar remains active, constantly seeking new rewards and improving its performance.
It is crucial that these avatars have the ability to evolve and learn, allowing them to behave like real people. Through this development, they could not only enrich interactions with users but also foster a sense of community and support. Such a center for happiness on the internet could contribute to creating a positive and welcoming digital environment where everyone feels at home. With a website like this, someone could make billions of dollars. $$$
